title: California's Hobo Paradise
summary: Homelessness explodes, but the state's liberals are in denial.. President Trump performed a public service last week by highlighting the causes of exploding homelessness in California. Democrats aren't taking it well, but this is a debate the U.S. and especially the Golden State need.

title: Releasing the Ukraine Transcript
summary: The call will leak eventually, so Trump might as well get it out.. Democrats are having another impeachment moment, and this time they think they have the goods with Donald Trump's phone-call request that Ukraine's President investigate Joe Biden and his son Hunter for their Ukraine interventions. The best defense for Mr. Trump here is a good offense, specifically releasing the transcript of his call.

summary: The striking union figures out that electric cars will cost jobs.. title: Protecting Unborn Children Is No 'Cosmic Question'
summary: Despite Roe v. Wade, the courts have upheld many laws that mark conception as life's clear beginning.. title: Iraq Is Committed to Mideast Stability
summary: We're inviting our neighbors to convene in Baghdad and chart a map for a regional alliance.. Recent events are a stark reminder of how volatile the Middle East remains and how easily local enmity can damage the interests of the rest of the world. The attacks on oil installations in Saudi Arabia are cause for alarm, but the underlying problem isn't new. The harrowing conflicts in Yemen and Syria have brought instability and suffering, and external actors fueled the flames.

title: Red-Flag Laws Could Stop Suicides
summary: Let mental-health professionals petition for the temporary removal of guns from their patients.. The Extreme Risk Protection Order and Violence Prevention Act may stop some mass shootings, but it could save even more Americans from suicide.

title: 'The Will of the People' Review: The Gentle Art of Breaking Away
summary: What made the American revolutionary experience so different from the cruel, bloody and often vindictive rebellions elsewhere?. The stirring and ominous term "revolution" conjures the lurid image of an established order violently overthrown. In the post-Enlightenment era, it is the French Revolution that first comes to mind, from the fall of the Bastille through the reign of terror. A similar sort of political spectacle, both bloody and cruel, played out in Russia and China in the 20th century. The American Revolution, though, seems to follow a separate pattern. In "The Will of the People," T.H. Breen, a distinguished historian of colonial America, looks closely at the struggle for American independence and asks what made the American revolutionary experience so different.

summary: Pundits think Trump won't fight. But as sanctions bite, Tehran could cross a line.. The scare faded as pundits concluded that underneath the chest-thumping, Donald Trump was more chicken than hawk-that for all his "cocked and loaded" bluster, he is ultimately willing to let Iran get away with mayhem in the Gulf and possibly even willing to cut a new deal with Tehran on its terms.

title: Vaping Isn't for Everyone, but It Helps Many
summary: As one who started smoking at 15, and only quit at 70 because the grandkids moved in, I can testify to the effectiveness of e-cigarettes. They are the perfect tool to move away from "combustible" cigarettes.. Liam Sigaud and Steve Pociask's "A Vaping Ban Will Send Smokers Back to the Pack" (op-ed, Sept. 13) is 100% correct. If society attempts to remove all imperfections via bans on what it perceives as harmful, we will approach totalitarianism. We who are less-than-perfect will seek those crutches that get us through difficult times without harming others. I credit nicotine for keeping me away from marijuana.

title: On the Fed's Mandate and Its Performance
summary: Since 1968 the Fed's record at meeting its three-pronged statutory objectives hasn't been strong.. Thank you, Judy Shelton, for covering the third of the Federal Reserve's statutory obligations: moderate long-term interest rates ("The Fed's Mandate Is Up to Congress and the President," op-ed, Sept. 17). While she points out one of the problems with the failure to have moderate rates, other problems include the inability of pension plans and insurance companies to rely on bonds to produce the returns they need to meet their long-term obligations, thus causing significant moves toward equities. The wealth gap increases as a result.

title: Tailgaiting With Tosca and Tamino at Santa Fe Opera
summary: Obviously, Joe Queenan has never been to the Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico, where tailgating is a very big thing. Obviously, Joe Queenan has never been to the Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico, where tailgating is a very big thing ("Moving Targets: Tailgating Could Make Everything Better," Review, Sept. 14). Some people dress up for this, bringing table, tablecloth, wine glasses, gourmet dinners, etc. Others are more casual. But the tailgating is a very social thing and anyone passing by, including nontailgaters, can strike up a conversation with those who are, complimenting them on their layout or clothes or food. It is all very congenial. So, Mr. Queenan, it has already been done! And, as with sporting events, it does make the opera that much more of a delightful experience.

title: Sheryl Crow on Recording Her Final Album
summary: The Americana songwriter on her star-studded album Threads and what it's like to make music with her heroes. On the eve of the release of what she has said is her final album, Sheryl Crow is on the back porch of her home in Nashville, in her house slippers with a cup of coffee. It's a late August morning, milder than usual for Nashville, and Crow is just back from a girls' trip to Blackberry Mountain, a resort in the Great Smoky Mountains in Walland, Tennessee. Though confident in her decision, she says that Threads, which came out August 30 from The Valory Music Co., will be her final "full artistic statement." The record is a culmination of sorts of the songwriter's decades-long career, a testament to the friendships and connections she's made in her career.

summary: Company and union bargainers are still at odds over wages, temporary workers and profit-sharing. The United Auto Workers strike at General Motors Co. is heading into its second week as union and company bargainers face unresolved issues ranging from the use of temporary workers to wages for newer hires, according to people close to the talks.

title: 'Game of Thrones,' 'Fleabag' Win Top Honors at Emmys
summary: This year's telecast marked a changing of the guard, as long-dominant series bowed out and younger shows came to the fore. "Game of Thrones," the HBO series that pushed television production to new levels of scale and spending, ended its run at the Emmy Awards without completely torching the competition.

title: 2019 Emmy Awards Winners
summary: 'Game of Thrones' and 'Fleabag' take top prizes at 71st Primetime Emmy Awards. Here is the complete list of winners of the 71st Primetime Emmy Awards

title: Aramco's Repairs Could Take Months Longer Than Company Anticipates, Contractors Say
summary: Saudi oil company tells contractors to spare no expense getting facilities in working order after attacks. The Saudi Arabian Oil Co. is in emergency talks with equipment makers and service providers, offering to pay premium rates for parts and repair work as it attempts a speedy recovery from missile attacks on its largest oil-processing facilities, Saudi officials and oil contractors said.

title: The Coming Currency War: Digital Money vs. the Dollar
summary: Central banks are getting closer to issuing their own digital currency. If they do, the dollar might finally face real competition as the world's dominant currency. The future of money might be a digital version of the cash that's already in people's wallets-potentially upending the currency system that the world has known for many decades.

title: Bonds That Do Good-and, Maybe, Well
summary: Social and impact bonds aim to provide a return for investors while addressing important social causes. Bonds are now lending philanthropy a hand.

title: How to Keep Your Mobile Banking Safe
summary: A lot of it depends on your bank, but there are things customers can do as well. As people increasingly do their banking on mobile devices, concerns about digital security have come to the forefront.

title: Startups That Offer New Paths to Homeownership
summary: Startups are creating new ways for consumers shut out of the traditional mortgage market to be able to join the ranks of homeowners. People with steady incomes but less-than-perfect credit are often shut out of buying homes because they can't qualify for a mortgage.

title: Investors in Search of Yield Turn to Music-Royalty Funds
summary: These funds buy the rights to music catalogs and then generate royalty payments for investors. Betting your money on Keith Richards might sound risky. But at a time when some $15 trillion in government bonds around the world have negative yields, it might not be a bad wager.

title: The Potentially High Cost of Not Disclosing ESG Data
summary: Activist investors push companies to disclose information about their environmental and social impact. Many companies have resisted disclosing environmental, social and governance data out of fear of being shunned by investors. These days, not disclosing that information may be even more risky.

title: Small ESG Investors Punch Above Their Weight
summary: Niche investors are often able to spur companies to address ESG issues. A small group of niche investors guided by environmental, social and governance principles are emerging as a big influence on corporate decision making.

title: Chinese Tech Companies Turn to Financial Services
summary: In search of new growth markets, they hope to leverage their consumer data to sell loans, insurance and more. China's biggest internet and technology companies are crowding into the financial-services business, hoping to monetize troves of data they've collected on millions of people in the country.

title: Oddball Policies Give Boost to China's Insurers
summary: The country's high internet penetration lets insurance companies market their products to a large population via apps. For about $70 a year, one of China's largest internet-only insurers will make a lump-sum payout to parents if their child goes missing.

title: Mutual-Fund Ratings Are Often Based on a Decade's Results. That's Too Short.
summary: The most recent decade hasn't had a bear market for large-cap funds. The future ain't what it used to be, Yogi Berra said. But now, when it comes to evaluating mutual funds and ETFs, it seems the past ain't what it used to be either.

title: China Will Live or Die by Its Digital Economy
summary: The digital economy is one of the few good options China has to keep growing rapidly. For China, technological leadership is an existential issue.

title: Some Important Dates in World Currency History
summary: Resume Subscription. No one can say whether digital currencies will one day be the global payment of preference, or whether perhaps a different national currency will replace the dollar as the de facto world currency. Here's a look at some important events in the past that have helped shape today's global currency issues.

title: NYSE Owner Launches Long-Awaited Bitcoin Futures
summary: Intercontinental Exchange bets consumers, businesses and Wall Street will embrace cryptocurrencies. The owner of the New York Stock Exchange launched its long-delayed market for bitcoin futures Sunday, a high-profile bet that consumers, businesses and Wall Street will embrace cryptocurrencies.
